subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Parralel Systems
msgSnippet: I am not sure I agree with the suggestion that junior QS was intended to be the default alphabet with senior QS for handwriting alone.  I think of junior as
messageBody:
I am not sure I agree with the suggestion that junior QS was intended to be the default alphabet with senior QS for handwriting alone.  I think of junior as being for beginners while they are still getting used to the alphabet.  I find that senior makes more distinctive word shapes, which are easier to remember without the necessity of "sounding the letters out," i.e. sight recognition is improved, and it may even may make reading faster to those adept in senior.

I see the distinction between senior and junior as similar to that of printed T.O. and cursive T.O.  In the past, cursive was not practical to use for printed material so almost everything was printed in disconnected letters.  Cursive writing was reserved for handwriting.  But that is no longer necessary.  Computer technology should be able to make the use of senior forms relatively easy, so why should we not use the senior form in material printed for proficient readers? 

It is my understanding that Arabic letters change their shape depending on their location in a word without causing distress to Arabic readers.  Should not QS have the flexibility to use the senior forms in printed material if the writer prefers it?  The senior forms are  more fluid and aesthetically appealing to me than the junior version of the alphabet.

Paige

Ph.D. wrote:

Del Ray skribis:
>
> Dr-o Phil kaj Tim:
>
> I can't imagine that anyone seriously thinks that QS
> might supplant Latin for writing English. Shaw might
> have thought that about Shavian, but did Kingsley
> Read even think that about QS?

That's a good question. Shavian was intended to be
the default writing system for English, but what did
Read intend for QS? I've always assumed that he
intended junior QS to become the default alphabet
for English with senior QS as a shorthand for handwriting.

--Ph. D.


(Al S-ro Del Ray: Fakte mi ne estas doktoro. "Ph. D."
nur estas mallongigo de mia nomo. Eble mi povus
uzi "Ph.D., B.S." sed tio sxajnas kiel ia sxerco.)
